DOCNAME: CASE OF PECK v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 8;Violation of Art. 13;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG ( “ the Council ” ) approved guidelines for the operation and management of ORG . The ORG tape recordings would be retained initially for DATE , this period to be reviewed from time to time and reduced to a minimum , and the tapes would be erased on completion of the storage period . In the section headed “ privacy to neighbouring properties ” , it was noted that the ORG system should ensure adequate provision for the avoidance of unwarranted intrusion in areas surrounding those under surveillance . In the event of it becoming apparent that privacy was being violated , it was foreseen that the ORG would take such steps as to ensure that “ either an electronic ( digital ) screening or physical screening is taking place ” . In DATE the ORG installed a ORG surveillance system in GPE . It was fully operational by DATE . The ORG 's monitoring operator had a direct visual and audio link to the police so that if it was considered that an incident warranting police intervention was taking place , the images being captured could be switched through to the police .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant was suffering from depression as a result of personal and family circumstances . On DATE at TIME he walked alone down the high street towards a central junction in the centre of GPE with a kitchen knife in his hand and he attempted to commit suicide by cutting his wrists . He stopped at the junction and leaned over a railing facing the traffic with the knife in his hand . He was unaware that a ORG camera , mounted on the traffic island in front of the junction , filmed his movements . The ORG footage later disclosed did not show the applicant cutting his wrists , the operator being solely alerted to an individual in possession of a knife at the junction .

CARDINAL . The police were notified by the ORG operator and arrived . They took the knife from the applicant , gave him medical assistance and brought him to the police station . He was detained under LAW DATE . His custody record refers to the self - inflicted injuries to his wrists on arrival and notes that he was examined and treated by a doctor , after which he was released without charge and taken home by police officers .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG working party of the ORG agreed to authorise the release of regular press features on the ORG system . The ORG also decided to cooperate with third parties in the preparation of factual programmes concerning their ORG system .

CARDINAL . The ORG 's first press feature , ORG , was released on CARDINAL DATE and included CARDINAL photographs taken from the ORG footage of the applicant to accompany an article entitled “ Defused – The partnership between ORG and the police prevents a potentially dangerous situation ” . The applicant 's face was not specifically masked . The article noted that an individual had been spotted with a knife in his hand , that he was clearly unhappy but not looking for trouble , that the police had been alerted , that the individual had been disarmed and brought to the police station where he was questioned and given assistance for his problems . The article included the name of a ORG employee in the event that readers wished to obtain copies of the pictures .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG used a photograph of the incident involving the applicant on its front page to accompany an article on the use and benefits of the ORG system . The applicant 's face was not specifically masked .

CARDINAL . On DATE an article entitled “ Gotcha ” appeared in ORG , a local newspaper with a circulation of CARDINAL . The article was accompanied by a photograph of the applicant taken from the ORG footage . The newspaper article referred to the applicant having been intercepted with a knife and a potentially dangerous situation being defused as a result of the ORG system . It was noted that the applicant had been released without charge .

CARDINAL . As a result ORG sought , and the ORG provided , footage of the incident involving the applicant . On DATE extracts from that footage were included in its news programme about the ORG system , a local broadcast to an average audience of CARDINAL . The applicant 's face had been masked at the ORG 's oral request . However , that masking was later considered inadequate by ORG ( see below ) , the applicant 's distinctive hairstyle and moustache making him easily recognisable to anyone who knew him .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Chairman of ORG informed ORG that cooperation had been , and would continue to be , given in the preparation of factual documentary programmes concerning the ORG system . He referred to the feature on ORG which had been broadcast by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . In DATE or DATE the applicant became aware that he had been filmed on ORG and that footage had been released because a neighbour told his partner that the former had seen him on television . He did not take any action then as he was still suffering from severe depression .

CARDINAL . On DATE a second article entitled “ Eyes in the sky triumph ” was published in ORG outlining the benefits of ORG in the fight against crime and was accompanied by the same photograph as had been previously used by that newspaper . It appears that a number of people recognised the applicant . A letter of DATE from the ORG opined that the applicant was not identifiable . ORG did not decide whether or not the applicant was identifiable from the photograph ( see below ) .

CARDINAL . At or about that time the ORG agreed to furnish ORG footage of , inter alios , the applicant to the producers of “ Crime Beat ” , a series on ORG national television with an average of CARDINAL viewers . ORG imposed orally a number of conditions on the producers including that no one should be identifiable in the footage and that all faces should be masked . The ORG were also to consult with the police to ensure that they had “ no objection to recordings being shown because of sub judice issues ” .

CARDINAL . DATE the applicant was told by friends that they had seen him on DATE in trailers for an episode of “ Crime Beat ” which was to be broadcast soon . On DATE he complained to the ORG about the forthcoming programme , at which stage the ORG became aware of his identity . The ORG contacted the producers who confirmed that his image had been masked . That evening the ORG footage was shown on “ Crime Beat ” . The applicant 's image was masked in the main programme itself but ORG ( see below ) later found that masking inadequate . Many of the applicant 's friends and family who saw the programme recognised the applicant .

CARDINAL . In response to the applicant 's request for a copy of the ORG 's licence agreement with the producers of “ Crime Beat ” , by letter dated DATE , the ORG provided an unsigned and undated agreement which did not appear to relate to the applicant but which contained a requirement to mask all faces in any copies of the relevant video . By letter dated DATE the ORG confirmed that it could not locate a signed copy of the agreement with the producers but it included an earlier draft of that agreement which had been signed by the producers , which related to the footage of the applicant but which did not include any masking requirement .

CARDINAL . The applicant made a number of media appearances thereafter to speak out against the publication of the footage and photographs . On DATE he participated in a national radio programme ( ORG CARDINAL ) . On DATE he spoke to a journalist who published an article in a national newspaper and this was the first time the applicant 's name appeared in the media . Other newspaper articles included photographs of the applicant or quotes given by him . He also appeared on national television : on DATE on ORG “ Right to Reply ” , on DATE on ORG “ GPE and on DATE on ORG CARDINAL 's “ You Decide ” . He also had his photograph published in ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with the ORG in relation to , inter alia , the “ Crime Beat ” programme alleging an unwarranted infringement of his privacy and that he had received unjust and unfair treatment . On DATE the ORG upheld both of his complaints .

CARDINAL . The ORG noted that the ORG had already accepted that it had meant to mask the applicant 's image and that this had not been done in the trailer due to an oversight . The ORG also considered the masking during the programme inadequate as the applicant had been recognised by viewers who had not seen the trailer . It was accepted that the ORG had not intended that the applicant would be identifiable . However , the ORG found that the effect was to reveal to the applicant 's family , friends and neighbours an episode which he did not wish to reveal , and that the outcome had been distressing and amounted to an unwarranted infringement of his privacy . The ORG added that the fact that the applicant later chose to speak publicly about this incident did not alter the infringement established . The ORG was directed to broadcast a summary of the adjudication of the ORG with the episode of “ Crime Beat ” on DATE and a summary of the adjudication was also published in ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained to the ORG in respect of the broadcast by ORG . The latter had already apologised to the applicant and conceded that it had breached the privacy requirements of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ( sections concerning coverage of events in public and scenes of suffering and distress ) . The ORG noted that the implication was that a man carrying a knife was likely to be intent on a criminal act . It found that the applicant 's identity was not adequately obscured and that he was readily identifiable and easily recognisable by those who knew him . It found that section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW had been breached and the decision of the ORG was published in its ORG and Interventions Report of DATE . Given the admission and apology by ORG , no further action was taken by the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained to the ORG in respect of the articles published in ORG . The ORG rejected the applicant 's complaint without a hearing and the decision was communicated to the applicant by letter dated DATE . The ORG considered that , whether or not the applicant was identifiable from the photographs , the events in question took place in a town high street , open to public view . It did not consider that the juxtaposition of the photographs and the articles implied that the applicant had committed a crime and it had been made clear that he was released without charge , the second article indicating that the applicant was ill at the relevant time .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied to ORG for leave to apply for judicial review of the ORG 's disclosure of the ORG material arguing , inter alia , that that disclosure had no basis in law . On DATE a single judge of ORG refused leave . On DATE the High Court granted leave on a renewed request and leave to amend the application to include a complaint that the disclosure was irrational , even if lawful .

CARDINAL . By judgment dated DATE ORG rejected the application for judicial review . It found that the purpose of section CARDINAL of ORG “ the DATE LAW ) was to empower a local authority to provide ORG equipment in order to promote the prevention of crime or the welfare of victims of crime :

“ By publicising information about the successful operation of the ORG , the ORG was providing information about its effectiveness and thereby reinforcing the deterrent effect of its operation . The making available to the media of footage from the ORG film to show the effectiveness of the system can properly be said ... to be incidental to and to facilitate the discharge of the ORG 's function under LAW [ of LAW ] because it thereby increased , or tended to increase , the preventative effect of the equipment which [ the ORG was ] providing for the purposes of the prevention of crime . ”

CARDINAL . It concluded that the ORG had the power to distribute the ORG footage to the media by virtue of section CARDINAL of LAW DATE in the discharge of their functions under section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act .

CARDINAL . As to the “ rationality ” of the ORG 's decision to disclose , the applicant submitted that the ORG acted irrationally in disclosing the footage with the aim of crime prevention when he had not been , in fact , involved in any criminal activity . He argued that by failing to consult the police to see if he had been charged with a criminal offence and to impose sufficient restrictions as regards disclosure of his identity , the ORG had facilitated an unwarranted invasion of his privacy which was contrary to the spirit , if not the letter , of the ORG 's guidelines .
CARDINAL . The High Court judge had some sympathy with that submission but did not consider it correct in law . He went on :

“ I have some sympathy with the applicant who has suffered an invasion of his privacy , as is borne out by the findings of ORG and ORG . However , if I am right in deciding that the ORG does have power to distribute the film footage from its ORG system , there may on occasion be undesirable invasions of privacy . Unless and until there is a general right of privacy recognised by LANGUAGE law ( and the indications are that there may soon be so by incorporation of ORG into our law ) , reliance must be placed on effective guidance being issued by Codes of practice or otherwise , in order to try and avoid such undesirable invasions of a person 's privacy .

The evidence is that the ORG cameras in public places play an important role in both crime prevention and crime detection . In this case , the film footage showed a man walking in the High Street carrying a large knife in his hand . It did not show him attempting to commit suicide . It was plainly a potentially dangerous situation which the ORG 's monitoring employee quite properly put to the police , as a result of which the man was arrested . ... It was not unreasonable for the ORG to conclude that the footage was a useful example of how a potentially dangerous situation can be avoided . ... In those circumstances , it seems to me that the decision of the ORG to distribute the film footage to the media could not be said to be irrational or unreasonable , bearing in mind that the film did not show an attempted suicide and that , at the time , they did not know the applicant 's identity . They therefore had no reason to consult the police as to whether an offence had been committed . They did not sell the take - outs from the ORG footage for commercial gain and , more importantly , they had imposed on the television companies a requirement that an individual 's face should be masked . It is true that that was a verbal rather than a written requirement , but I am not persuaded that what happened was likely to have been different if it had been a written requirement . In the event , the fault lay with the television companies . ORG failed to mask the applicant 's identity adequately . The ORG failed to mask the applicant 's identity at all in the trailers . As soon as the ORG were notified about that by the applicant , DATE before the programme went out , which was the first time they were aware of the applicant 's identity , they immediately contacted the ORG and received assurances that his image had been masked in the programme . In the event , unknown to the ORG , it had not been adequately masked in the programme .

I am sure that lessons can be learnt from this unfortunate incident , and it may be that , with the benefit of hindsight , the ORG will want to see if they can tighten up their guidelines to seek to avoid a similar incident in the future . I am , however , equally sure that , in the circumstances that I have described , the ORG can not be said to have acted irrationally in the sense that they had taken leave of their senses or had acted in a manner in which no reasonable local authority could sensibly have acted . ”
CARDINAL . An application to ORG for leave to appeal to ORG was rejected . The subsequent leave application to a single judge of ORG was rejected on DATE because

“ ... the [ High Court ] Judge was plainly correct in his interpretation of the relevant statutory provisions and the ORG was neither acting outside its statutory authority nor irrationally in making the film and photographs available to the media . The injury , of which complaint is made , arises from a failure on the part of the media to sufficiently disguise the applicant when making the film and photographs visible to the public . That is and has been the subject of complaint against the media involved but is not capable of supporting a claim for a declaration against ORG ” .
CARDINAL . Following an oral hearing before the full ORG , the applicant 's leave application was dismissed on DATE .
CARDINAL . The Criminal Justice and LAW DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) came into force on DATE . The relevant parts of CARDINAL provide as follows :

“ CARDINAL . Without prejudice to any power which they may appear to exercise for those purposes under any other enactment , a local authority may take such of the following steps as they consider will , in relation to their area , promote the prevention of crime or the welfare of the victims of crime –
( a ) providing apparatus for recording visual images of events occurring on any land in their area ;
( b ) providing within their area a telecommunications system which , under Part II of LAW DATE , may be run without a licence ;
( c ) arranging for the provision of any other description of telecommunications system within their area or between any land in their area and any building occupied by a public authority .

CARDINAL . Any power to provide , or to arrange for the provision of , any apparatus includes power to maintain , or operate , or , as the case may be , to arrange for the maintenance or operation of , that apparatus . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant part of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE provides as follows :

“ Without prejudice to any powers exercisable apart from this section but subject to the provisions of this LAW and any other enactment passed before or after this LAW , a local authority shall have the power to do anything ... which is calculated to facilitate , or is conducive or incidental to the discharge of any of their functions . ”

CARDINAL . Essex Police Policy Guidelines dated DATE concern the involvement of the police in the installation and operation of ORG systems in their remit . In the section concerning the release to the media of video footage , it was pointed out that care should be taken not to jeopardise any existing or future legal proceedings , that licence agreements covering all appropriate terms and conditions of release should be drawn up and that care should always be taken to ensure that victims or other innocent parties featured were aware of its potential use and , where possible , their consent obtained . Where possible , the identity of victims , police employees and suspects ( where identification might jeopardise criminal proceedings ) should be masked .

CARDINAL . As an extension of ORG announced in DATE , government funding for ORG systems was introduced in DATE and the sum of MONEY ( GBP ) has been made available over DATE , of which MONEY has already been allocated to CARDINAL ORG schemes . CARDINAL of the requirements of such funding is that the scheme should be regulated by a suitable code of practice to ensure that it operates fairly and with proper respect for personal privacy . In DATE of operation of the ORG system in GPE , there was a PERCENT reduction in crime .

CARDINAL . Where a public authority has exceeded its powers or has acted irrationally or has reached a decision in breach of the rules of procedural fairness , then a person aggrieved may challenge the decision by means of a judicial review . If a decision is so disproportionate to its intended objective as to be irrational , the ORG will strike it down . The LANGUAGE courts do not recognise proportionality as a separate head of judicial review . However , in the case of NORP ( ORG ) v. Secretary of ORG for ORG ( [ DATE ] CARDINAL Weekly Law Reports CARDINAL ) , Lord PERSON of ORG stated obiter dictum :

“ I consider that even without reference to LAW DATE the time has come to recognise that this principle [ of proportionality ] is part of LANGUAGE administrative law , not only when judges are dealing with Community acts but also when they are dealing with acts subject to domestic law . ”

CARDINAL . The remedy of breach of confidence is made up of CARDINAL essential elements : the information itself must have “ the necessary quality of confidence about it ” ; the information “ must have been imparted in circumstances importing an obligation of confidence ” ; and there must have been an “ unauthorised use of that information to the detriment of the party communicating it ” ( PERSON v. ORG [ DATE ] Reports of Patent Cases CARDINAL , at p. CARDINAL ) . A fuller description of this cause of action together with more recent domestic case - law are detailed in PERSON and PERSON v. GPE ( applications nos . CARDINAL and DATE , Commission decision of DATE , Decisions and Reports ( GPE ) CARDINALA , p. CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Where a public official abuses his position by performing an administrative act maliciously , or which he knows he has no power to do , and causes foreseeable harm , then the injured person may recover damages on the basis of misfeasance in public office .

CARDINAL . The remedy of defamation is well established in LANGUAGE law . Every person is entitled to his good name and to the esteem in which he is held by others and has a right to claim that his reputation shall not be disparaged by defamatory statements made about him to a third person or persons without lawful justification or excuse .

CARDINAL . The essential elements of malicious falsehood are that a defendant has published words about the claimant that are false , that they were published maliciously and that special damage has followed as a direct and natural result of their publication ( PERSON [ DATE ] FAC CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The tort of nuisance consists of an unwarranted interference with the use or enjoyment of land ( see , for example , ORG [ DATE ] Law Reports : ORG ) . ORG consists of an unjustifiable intrusion by CARDINAL person upon the land in the possession of another . The domestic courts have been developing the concept of a tort of harassment causing personal injury ( see , for example , PERSON v. PERSON [ DATE ] CARDINAL Family Law Reports CARDINAL , and GPE v. PERSON [ DATE ] CARDINAL All England Law Reports CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Depending on the circumstances in which any film has been made or published , the unauthorised taking or publication of pictures might be prevented ( or damages recovered ) on the grounds of copyright , breach of contract or inducing breach of contract .

CARDINAL . Statute law provides certain protection in the form of ORG . Statutory regulation of surveillance is provided by ORG DATE , by LAW DATE and by LAW . The purpose of LAW is to ensure that the relevant investigatory powers of the authorities are used in accordance with human rights . Many users of ORG will have to comply with the provisions of LAW DATE . Specific statutory protection of privacy is accorded in certain other contexts such as the anonymity of rape victims ( Sexual Offences LAW DATE ) and the prohibition of the publication of the names or photographs of children involved in legal proceedings ( Children and Young Persons Act DATE ) .

CARDINAL . LAW DATE came into force in DATE . It requires that , so far as it is possible to do so , primary and subordinate legislation be read and given effect in a manner compatible with LAW and further provides that it is unlawful for a public authority to act in a way incompatible with a Convention right .

In PERSON ( [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL ) , ORG indicated that he was prepared to find that there was now a qualified right to privacy under NORP domestic law , although other members of ORG ( PERSON and PERSON ) did not find it necessary to rule on that point .

CARDINAL . ORG ( ORG ) was established by LAW with effect from DATE . It is the duty of the ORG to draw up and publish a code giving guidance as to the principles to be observed and practices to be followed in connection with the avoidance of unjust or unfair treatment in programmes or the unwarranted infringement of privacy in programmes ( section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act ) . In this respect , paragraph CARDINAL of the code points out that broadcasters should take care with material recorded by ORG cameras to ensure identifiable individuals are treated fairly and that “ any exceptions to the requirement of individual consent would have to be justified by an overriding public interest ” . The ORG is also required to consider and adjudicate on complaints relating to unjust or unfair treatment in programmes , or to unwarranted infringement of privacy in programmes ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE Act ) .

CARDINAL . The ORG has powers , inter alia , to direct broadcasting bodies to publish the findings of the ORG or a summary of them ( section CARDINAL ) , but it has no powers to direct a broadcasting body not to broadcast a programme .

CARDINAL . ORG ( ORG ) is a public body set up by LAW DATE to licence and regulate commercially funded television ( excluding television services provided by , inter alia , the ORG ) . The LAW requires the ORG to draw up and enforce a code governing programming standards and practice , which code covers issues of privacy . The ORG adjudicates upon complaints made under the code and , where a breach is confirmed , the ORG may impose sanctions such as requiring on - screen apologies , ordering fines and revoking licences .

CARDINAL . ORG ( ORG ) is a non - statutory body set up by the newspaper industry for the purposes of self - regulation . The ORG operates a voluntary code of practice , which code includes provisions relating to privacy . If a newspaper is found to be in breach of the code , the newspaper is to publish the adjudication of the ORG . The ORG has no legal powers to prevent publication of material , to enforce its rulings or to grant any legal remedies to a complainant .
